explanation:
Rationale for each symbol (why it is needed to determine compliance with the MISRA for-loop rule):

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Direct callee of OS_BinSemFlush. Any for-loops in its body (or in functions it calls) form part of the target function's observable behaviour and must be checked for the three clauses, loop-counter usage, side-effects, and modifications in the body.

- OS_BinSemFlush_Impl: Direct callee that is executed when ObjectIdGetById returns success. Its body may contain for-loops (including nested or in-called functions); those loops must be inspected for well-formedness and for whether loop counters or other objects modified in the body violate the rule.

- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: These are callees of OS_ObjectIdGetById (transitive callees). To fully analyze for-loops reachable from OS_BinSemFlush, their implementations must be checked (they may contain loops or modify objects used as loop counters elsewhere).

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex: Callees of OS_BinSemFlush_Impl. Included for the same reason: any for-loops they contain (or objects they modify) are part of the effective behaviour of OS_BinSemFlush and must be checked against the MISRA requirements.

- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: These appear in the static call graph as callees of OS_BinSemFlush (test/harness stubs or instrumentation). If present in the compiled control flow they must be inspected because their for-loops (or side-effects on objects used as loop counters/flags) contribute to the overall behaviour and could violate the rule.

- OS_object_token_t: Type of the local variable token passed by address to callees. The structure layout tells whether fields of token could be used as loop counters or loop control flags in called functions or whether passing &token allows body functions to modify objects used in loop clauses; this is necessary to determine if loop counters are modified in the loop body.

- osal_id_t: Type of sem_id parameter. Called functions may use sem_id as part of loop conditions or counters; knowing its type (and whether it aliases other objects) is necessary to decide if a loop clause uses objects modified in the loop body.

- int32: Definition of return_code type (signedness/width) can matter for loop-counter/condition reasoning (e.g., arithmetic/wrap behaviour) when analyzing loops in callees that use return values or counters of this type.

- OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE: Macros/enum values passed into OS_ObjectIdGetById. These parameters can change control flow inside that function and its callees (which may contain loops), so their definitions are needed to understand which code paths (and loops) are actually reachable.

- OS_SUCCESS: The success return code tested in OS_BinSemFlush controls whether OS_BinSemFlush_Impl is called. Its value and meaning are required to determine whether the potentially looping code in the impl is executed and thus must be considered for MISRA compliance.

In short: to determine compliance with the MISRA for-loop rule you must analyze not only OS_BinSemFlush but every function it calls (directly and transitively) and any type/macros that affect which code paths and loop constructs are reachable or what objects are used/modified as loop counters or loop-control flags.
